thread.title: Government accused of risking another Windrush scandal with new housing rules

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Government accused of risking another Windrush scandal with new housing rules
text:
News Government accused of risking another Windrush scandal with new housing rules Former Newcastle Council leader Jeremy Beecham criticises laws that could allow landlords to keep deposits from rejected tenants Share Jeremy Beecham at home in Gosforth, Newcastle (Image: Newcastle Chronicle) Get daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
New rules allowing landlords to withhold deposits could lead to injustices along the lines of the Windrush scandal, the former leader of Newcastle City Council has warned.
Government legislation will allow landlords to keep “holding deposits” when they are paid by someone who turns out not to have the right to rent property in the UK.
It’s part of a measure designed to protect private housing tenants from unscrupulous landlords, by ensuring that in normal circumstances they get their deposit back.
But former council leader Jeremy Beecham, now a Labour shadow housing minister in the House of Lords, said he was concerned about plans to let landlords keep the money if a tenant had the wrong immigration status.
Speaking in the House of Lords, he asked: “Given the appalling record of the Home Office in the Windrush and other cases isn’t there a real risk of injustice in this provision?” Read More UK is 'closing in' on a Brexit deal, according to Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab
The Windrush scandal involved a policy, known as hostile environment, which was designed to make life difficult for people who had no legal right to be in the UK, including making it harder for them to rent a property.
It affected a number of British people who had moved to the UK from Commonwealth countries and had every right to be here, but lacked the necessary paperwork to prove it.
They were known as the Windrush generation after the HMT Empire Windrush, which bought migrants from Jamaica to London in 1948, although those affected had come from many different countries over a period of more than 20 years. Read More
